requirements:
A note on volunteer commitment:

Volunteer Advocates complete a one-time 30-hour core training and commit to serve for a minimum of one year after case assignment or until an assigned case is closed. In addition to dedicating at least 3-5 hours, more if necessary, each week on each case assigned, volunteers attend monthly group supervisions and in-service trainings. 

 

To Learn More:

To apply, submit an online application by visiting www.casa-nyc.org/volunteer-1. Upon receipt, CASA will contact you directly. We look forward to meeting you!
opportunity_id: Advocate for Foster Care Children and Youth
content_id:
Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) is a volunteer-based, non-profit organization working to ensure that children in foster care have their needs met and rights protected; that they move out of foster care and into permanent, safe and loving homes as quickly as possible; and that young people aging out of foster care have the resources and support they need to live independently. Family Court Judges assign CASA to assist with the most complex cases. To learn more, visit www.casa-nyc.org. 

 

Duties:

Volunteer Advocates conduct thorough research on the background of the case, reviewing documents and interviewing all parties involved. They report to the court, raising issues of concern that may interfere with a child's best interests and providing information that will help the judge make an informed decision. Volunteer Advocates can also play a pivotal role in assuring that a child or family is receiving services the court has ordered, such as physical or mental health services, substance abuse counseling or special education. During the life of a case, Volunteer Advocates monitor the child's situation to assure he or she remains safe and may be the only constant in the child's life as he or she moves through the bureaucratic maze of the child welfare system. Volunteers come from all backgrounds and need not have experience in legal or social services. The only requirement is a strong desire to help children who are in dire need of help.
summary: Advocate on behalf of foster care children and youth in New York City! Opportunities available in all 5 boroughs.
title: Court Appointed Special Advocates

requirements: Please complete our volunteer application: College Prep Tutor
content_id:
Overview:

College Prep Tutors work with seniors within the SBU college prep program, 1-on-1 or in small groups, to assist them in completing their high school graduation requirement to pass the NY State Regents Exams. Regents Exam topic areas cover the core academic subject areas (Math, History, Science, English); however, most students primarily need the extra support with Math, mainly algebra, and English. Tutors work with the same group of students every week. This provides tutors the opportunity to build relationships and to serve as a positive role model in youths' lives while also promoting the importance of education.

When:

Mondays 6:00 – 8:00pm
1st Semester: mid September - mid January
2nd Semester: early February - early June

Where:

Boys Prep School Building, Third Floor
192 E 151st Street
Bronx, NY 10451

Commitment:

Tutors are asked to commit to teaching on Mondays for at least one semester (Sept-Jan or Feb-June). However, if a tutor would like to be more involved, he/she is always welcome. Many of our College Prep Tutors also volunteer as College Mentors to aid their students in navigating the college application process.

Qualifications:

South Bronx United is looking for highly motivated, energetic volunteers who want to make a difference in the lives of South Bronx youth. Tutors should possess a strong grasp of at least one High School subject area and feel comfortable breaking down and explaining processes for problem solving. Our greatest need is typically for people with either strong Math or English skills; however, tutors are needed for all subject areas that are covered by the Regents Exams.

Training:

An orientation and training at the beginning of service will be run for all tutors to give general guidelines, tutoring tips and to go over the specific needs of the students. Additional training and "check ins" will be conducted intermittently throughout the course of the year.

Benefits:

In addition to helping provide the resources and support to allow under-served students to thrive in school, SBU is happy to connect with your school to see if your volunteer hours can work towards school service or academic requirements.

Beyond Tutoring:

The boys and girls participating in the program are also members of the South Bronx United Travel Soccer Teams. Tutors are welcome and encouraged to come out and see a game or get involved in a practice as SBU youth are extremely passionate about the sport and it’s a great way to connect with the kids.
summary: South Bronx United is looking for highly motivated, energetic volunteers who want to make a difference in the lives of South Bronx youth, providing the tools necessary to graduate high school and attend college.
title: South Bronx United

requirements: Please fill out our online application: ESOL Tutor
content_id:
Overview:

ESOL tutors work either 1-on-1 or with small groups of students in the South Bronx United Youth Development Program who are currently designated as English Language Learners (ELL). Tutoring is a mix of homework help and, for the Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors, a set curriculum aimed at ensuring that they pass the Regents Exams, SATs, and fulfill all of their graduation requirements respectively. This is the same course of study that all of the non-ELL students follow. Tutors meet with students, ages 11-18, for 2 hours on a set day every week. Tutors work with the same group of students every week. This provides tutors the opportunity to build relationships and to serve as a positive role model in youths' lives while also promoting the importance of education.

When:

  • 5th – 9th grade students come Monday through Thursday from 4:00 – 6:00pm.
  • 10th – 12th grade students come Monday and Wednesday from 6:00 – 8:00pm.
  • 1st Semester: September – January
  • 2nd Semester: February - June

Where:

Boys Prep School Building, Third Floor
192 E 151st Street
Bronx, NY 10451

Qualifications:

South Bronx United is looking for highly motivated, energetic volunteers who want to make a difference in the lives of South Bronx youth. Volunteers with some experience teaching ELL students are preferred. Proficiency in Spanish and/or French is also a plus. Volunteers should possess a general knowledge of 6th – 10th grade subject areas and feel comfortable teaching youth how to utilize the resources available to solve problems, guiding them through the process rather than simply providing answers. It’s not expected that tutors will be experts in all subject areas or know the answers to everything!!!

Commitment:

ESOL Teachers are asked to commit to 2 hours, one day a week for at least one semester (Sept-Jan or Feb-June). However, if a teacher would like to be more involved, he/she is always welcome.

Training:

An orientation and training will be provided before beginning service to provide general guidelines, best practices, tutoring tips and to go over the specific needs of the students.

Benefits:

In addition to helping provide the resources and support to allow underserved students to thrive in school, SBU is happy to connect with your school to see if your volunteer hours can work toward academic requirements.

Beyond Tutoring:

Youth participating in the program are also members of the South Bronx United Travel Soccer Teams. Tutors are welcome and encouraged to come out and see a game or get involved in a practice as SBU youth are extremely passionate about the sport and it’s a great way to connect with them.
summary: South Bronx United is looking for highly motivated, energetic volunteers who want to make a difference in the lives of South Bronx youth, providing the tools necessary to graduate high school and attend college.
title: South Bronx United

requirements: Interested persons should send a cover letter and a copy of their resume to info@southbronxunited.org Please put College Advisory Internship in the subject line.
content_id:
Overview:
South Bronx United's College Advisory Interns work closely with SBU's Director of College Guidance and Alumni to help coordinate and supervise the College Prep Program. Interns work 3 days per week and get hands on experience administering an educational program, tracking student progress towards college, and advising students on academic needs. The internship is perfect for those looking to gain experience in the fields of educational administration and college counseling.

When:
September - May
Mondays and Wednesdays 5:30-8:00pm + 1 extra day

Where:
Boys Prep School Building, Third Floor
192 E 151st Street
Bronx, NY 10451

Qualifications:

  • Enthusiastic and caring with a specific interest in education and youth empowerment.
  • Should have a background in working with youth.
  • Experience and knowledge of College Application process, Financial Aid, SUNY and CUNY college application processes
  • Bachelors Degree

Commitment:
A minimum of 3 days a week for one semester (NY public school semester, not college). 5:30 - 8:00pm on Mondays and Wednesdays is required. 3rd day is flexible.

Training:
All interns will receive training from the Director of College Guidance and Alumni.

Benefits:
While the position is unpaid, interns have the opportunity to work directly with our Director fo College Guidance and with our Director of Education Programs to lean firsthand the best practices for ensuring a pathway to college for all students.

Responsibilities in Detail:

  • Track program attendance and progress of all students
  • Family outreach/student outreach to improve student attendance at programs
  • Manage procurement and entry of student records and documents (transcripts, report cards, tax returns, waivers, etc.)
  • Research important college prep resources needed for each student (relevant scholarships, trade schools, additional SAT Prep & Regents Prep resources, GED option, etc.)
summary: South Bronx United is looking for highly motivated, energetic volunteers who want to make a difference in the lives of South Bronx youth, providing the tools necessary to graduate high school and attend college.
title: South Bronx United

requirements:
Qualifications:  Greeters must enjoy meeting and talking with people from diverse cultures and backgrounds.  They must be familiar with and upbeat about the neighborhoods that they want to show. Foreign language skills are a plus, especially ASL and Spanish.  It is essential that volunteers be comfortable using public transportation since it is the easiest way to get around New York City and we feel it helps make each visit to New York City even more like a slice of the daily life of a New Yorker.

While just about anyone who fits the qualifications can be a greeter, this is an ideal activity for senior citizens, retired or otherwise, who are outgoing and enjoy sharing their knowledge of the city with people from other places.

Time Commitment:  Greeters show New York City 7 days a week, 365 days a year. Each greeter must commit to a minimum of 1-3 visits per month, 4 hours per visit.
content_id:
Mission:  To enhance the worldwide image of New York City and enrich the New York experience by connecting visitors with knowledgeable and enthusiastic volunteers.

Activities:  Volunteers walk visitors throughout neighborhoods of New York City that they know well in all five boroughs. Visitors are able to experience the various sights and sounds with the greeter and can get a real taste of New York City and its inhabitants.  Many of our greeters are senior citizens who have had long experience of the neighborhoods they show.  Visits may include from one to six people.

Benefits:  There is a thrill in making new friends from all over the world and sharing the rewards of cross-cultural exchange.  If you speak a foreign language, here is your chance to practice it with native speakers.

As a greeter you will be able to show off the neighborhoods you know and love while helping to support the local businesses that help make your favorite neighborhoods so wonderful.  You will be able to promote a friendly, inviting and accessible image of New York City.
summary: Volunteers walk visitors throughout neighborhoods of New York City that they know well in all five boroughs. Visitors are able to experience the various sights and sounds with the greeter and can get a real taste of New York City and its inhabitants.  Many of our greeters are senior citizens.
title: Big Apple Greeter

opportunity_id: Give the Gift of Dance this Summer
content_id:
We are currently accepting applications for Volunteer Dance Teachers at Groove With Me, Inc. Groove With Me is a free dance school for girls in East Harlem. At GWM, we engage girls during the idle out-of-school hours when 90% of youth violence occurs; and seeks to decrease teen pregnancy, truancy, crime, violence, prostitution, substance abuse and gang related activity. East Harlem has the highest unmet need for after school programming of any neighborhood in NYC.

Our mission is to provide free classes and performance opportunities to promote leadership, pride, self-confidence, creativity, joy, and discipline they need to confront adversity they face in their daily lives and to empower them to grow into strong and healthy women.

By volunteering you provide:

  • much needed out-of-school time safety
  • arts programming
  • mentoring

If you are interested in this opportunity, or for further information please give me a call at 212-987-5910 or reach me via email at angie@groovewithme.org

Groove With Me, Inc.
186 E 123rd St
NY, NY 10035
Phone: 212-987-5910

Fax: 212-987-5080
www.groovewithme.org
summary: Groove With Me is a free dance school that utilizes dance to attract and engage girls during the idle out-of-school time hours; and build self-confidence in an effort to prevent risk-taking behaviors.

opportunity_id: Be a Mentor for our Creative Lab Program!
content_id:
What is the Creative Lab? 
 
Creative Lab offers teens an introduction to the creative industry and cultural institutions across New York City. Once a month, teens visit artist studios or attend workshops on professional development skills. Volunteer mentors meet twice a month with their teen (9th - 12th grade) to support them with career readiness and visual literacy skills. 

Mentor Responsibilities (October 2019 – June 2020)

  • 2 afternoons per month (group visit and one-on-one meeting)
  • 1-2 points of communication per month to support career readiness skill-building (via email, phone, skype)
  • Monthly online survey
  • Help teens explore their career interests, build their visual literacy, and increase their networks

Free Arts Provides:

  • Dedicated support by Free Arts NYC staff through quarterly check-ins
  • Two Youth Development trainings
  • Facilitated group workshops and career readiness curriculum
summary:
What is the Creative Lab? 
 
Creative Lab offers teens an introduction to the creative industry and cultural institutions across New York City.

requirements:
BOARD MEMBER ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

Lead organizational strategic planning, monitoring and evaluation.

Oversee and facilitate management success.

Support and evaluate the Executive Director.

Ensure adequate financial resources.

Protect assets and provide proper financial oversight.

Build an adept Board through recruitment, training and self-assessment.

Ensure legal and ethical integrity, as well as up-to-date policies.

Raise awareness and heighten visibility of Uweza.

Participate on Board committees.

 

ENGAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES 

I. DEEPENING PARTICIPATION AND KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT 

Read and familiarize yourself with Uweza case materials.

Travel to Kibera to see the program in action.

Keep updated on issues facing Kenyans and Uweza program participants.

 

II. SUPPORTING UWEZA EVENTS 

Provide names of potential donors to invite to donor cultivation events.

Host or co-host a donor cultivation event or house party at your home or office.

Identify potential donor cultivation event hosts/host homes.

Help plan Uweza fundraising events.

Attend Uweza fundraising events.

 

III. CONNECTING PERSONAL AND PROFESSIONAL NETWORKS TO UWEZA

Provide names and addresses of five or more potential donors for gifts at any level for our year-end appeal.

Review donor lists and provide information about people you know.

Make introductions to potential foundation or corporate donors.

Make introductions to potential in-kind donors.

Attend cultivation or solicitation meetings with major donors.

Suggest potential board members for Uweza.

Suggest potential special event leadership (co-chairs, host committee members).

Post, like and share our posts on social media.

 

IV. SHARING PERSONAL & PROFESSIONAL RESOURCES

Make Uweza one of your top three philanthropies for support.

Make a personally meaningful gift to Uweza.

Make Uweza the beneficiary of life cycle events, such as birthdays or anniversaries.

Host a Lunch & Learn at your office.

Offer corporate resources, such as meeting space for board or committee meetings.

Request in-kind support from vendors and colleagues at work.

Make a bequest to Uweza.

By becoming a volunteer crisis counselor, you’ll join a community of passionate volunteers who help students, save lives and are enriched through a truly meaningful experience.

The role of the crisis line volunteer is to provide support and assistance to victims via our HelpChat Line.

 

This includes listening, making appropriate referrals, and providing crisis intervention, while maintaining the highest levels of confidentiality. The role of the volunteer advocate is to provide support and assistance to youth 13-24.

Beginning with a comprehensive training program and continuing with on-going supervision and advanced trainings, STOMP Out Bullying™ ensures that each and every Crisis Counselor is prepared to deal with the wide range of issues they will confront on its Help Line. The online intensive Volunteer Training Program is taught by our experts. It is dynamic and highly interactive.

As a volunteer Help Chat Counselor, we offer a flexible schedule, but you would be asked to make a commitment to serve a certain number of hours per month. Pick the days and times that work best for you!

Work Remotely from Home

HOW TO APPLY

If you qualify, are interested, and can seriously make the commitment then we would love to hear from you. Please submit your resume(.pdf) and cover letter to us at info@stompoutbullying.org
summary: The STOMP Out Bullying HelpChat Line is a national and free crisis HelpChat Line. Volunteers use our web-based platform to provide emotional support to youth who are bullied, cyberbullied and at-risk for suicide.
title: STOMP Out Bullying

requirements:
All adult volunteers, or adult leaders of youth groups that volunteer at Trinity Human Services Center, must complete a volunteer form and be interviewed by the Director before they serve. 

In compliance with the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, the Center, housed at Most Holy Trinity - Saint Mary Parish, seeks to insure a Safe Environment for our clients, by requiring our staff and volunteers to attend Virtus training and submit to a background check before serving.

Any youth, between the ages of 12 and 18, who volunteer in groups, must be accompanied by adults from the school or church that is sending them to help out, at a ratio of one adult per four youths. 

Any youth, between the ages of 12 and 18, who volunteer alone, will be asked to work with and report to a specified adult staff member while at the Center.
opportunity_id: Helping clients/repacking shelves in "Client choice pantry", sorting items in Thrift Shop, and case management for two days a week.
content_id:
Trinity Human Services Corporation welcomes volunteers to assist in preparing its Client Choice Pantry: Deliveries of food are scheduled on Mondays from NYC Food Bank, City Harvest, and  WHERE ELSE? ...

Volunteers assess, move, sort, and arrange goods in the Pantry area according to Food Groups and Plentiful's allocation of points for different foodstuffs for family sizes and/or individual dietary needs.  Some volunteers also accompany clients, who can access the Pantry Tuesdays through Fridays from 9 am - 12 pm or 1 pm - 3 pm, through the pantry to make their selections of food to take home.  Others help arrange goods in our second-floor storage areas for later use, or replenish the Pantry area shelves from that storage area.

Volunteers in the Clothing and Household Goods Thrift Shop can sort, clean and arrange donated goods on Mondays and whenever needed.  Some volunteers assist clients in selecting what they need to take home.  

Volunteers in the Reception Area and/or Social Services Office help to welcome clients, provide orientation for them, and register them online.  Some may help manage flows of people who access our services on any given day and direct individuals to the areas they need to wait or access services.  The background and skills of volunteers in these areas will determine their placement.
summary: Trinity Human Services Corporation welcomes volunteers who can help in a Client Choice Model Food Pantry, or in a Thrift Shop sorting Clothing and Household Goods, and assisting those in selecting goods to fit their needs, or offer Social Service referrals and assistance to individuals and families.
title: Trinity Human services Corporation

content_id:
Overview:
Non-profit development interns work closely with South Bronx United’s Development Manager in building organizational capacity in support of SBU’s youth development programs, which use soccer as a tool to help youth advance academically, graduate high school, and go on to college. Intern’s work is focused in 3 key areas: 1) grant research & writing, 2) press relations and social media, and 3) fundraising through special events and sponsorships. Within these areas, the position can be molded to fit the individual's strengths and interests.

When:
Spring Internship: mid/late January – May
Fall Internship: September – December
Summer Internship: May – September

Where:
SBU Office, 5th Floor
192 E 151st Street
Bronx, NY 10451
*There is some flexibility to work remotely

Commitment:
10-15 hours a week for at least a semester.

Training:
All interns will be trained and supervised by the Executive Director.

Benefits:
While the position is unpaid, interns have the opportunity to see the inner workings of a small but growing non profit and get experience in providing the resources and support needed for program sustainability.
summary: Non-profit development interns work closely with South Bronx United’s Development Manager in building organizational capacity in support of SBU’s youth development programs, which use soccer as a tool to help youth advance academically, graduate high school, and go on to college.

requirements:
experience teaching dance

experience with children
content_id:
We are currently accepting applications for Volunteer Dance Teachers. Groove With Me is a free dance school for girls in East Harlem. It engages girls during the idle out-of-school hours when 90% of youth violence occurs; and seeks to decrease teen pregnancy, truancy, crime, violence, prostitution, substance abuse and gang related activity. East Harlem has the highest unmet need for after school programming of any neighborhood in NYC. By volunteering you provide much needed out-of-school time safety - and arts programming.

Here are the ways you can get involved:

  1. Full year volunteer teacher- Teaching at GWM requires a full year commitment (September-June) and mandatory teacher training. During the course of the year, you prepare your students for Parent Observation and Participation (POP) week in December and the End of Year Recital in June. There are also opportunities to perform at community events. We welcome all styles of dance!
  2. Subbing- Our teachers are great but sometimes things come up! If you want to be involved, but have a schedule that does not allow you to commit to a full year, we are always in need of dancers who can fill in and sub a dance class when the regularly schedule teacher cannot make it.

If any of the three opportunities interest you, please attach your most recent resume and what your preferences are in the following:

  1. Style of dance
  2. Age group
  3. Day of the week
  4. Time slot you would like (after school and Saturdays)

If you cannot commit to any of the above but want to get involved we have plenty of other opportunities such as 1 day volunteering, chaperoning, Young People’s Committee, etc…
summary: We are currently accepting applications for Volunteer Dance Teachers. Groove With Me is a free dance school for girls in East Harlem.
title: Groove With Me, Inc.

requirements: There are no requirements or prerequisites in order to take part.  We do ask that volunteers wear clothing they don't mind getting dirty and bring a water bottle if possible.
content_id:
We are looking for a small group of dedicated volunteers to join us in gardening and environmental stewardship activites along the Gowanus Canal!  The team will meet on Friday mornings from 9:30-11:30 to do activities such as planting, propagating, weeding, and watering in our native plant nursery and stewardship space. 

Additionally, the Gardening and Stewardship Team will have opportunities to engage in discussions with Gowanus Canal Conservancy staff about specific topics related to the Gowanus Canal.  

The Gardening and Stewardship Team is a wonderful opportunity to build community around making a positive environmental impact, as well as to learn more about the Gowanus Canal, a waterway whose vibrant ecology is often overlooked and misunderstood.
summary: We are looking for a small group of volunteers to join us on Friday mornings in gardening activities along the Gowanus Canal!
title: Gowanus Canal Conservancy - GCC

content_id:
Why Join FOSM?

Make an Impact – The Friends of St. Mary’s committee is dedicated to improving the quality of life for the children and young adults with complex medical conditions.

Grow your Career – Develop fundraising and leadership skills. FOSM hosts various fundraising events that benefit St. Mary’s Kids. Committee members take turns championing these events via leadership roles that assign responsibility for all necessary event planning and execution.

Share your Passion – Meet and work with other people who are committed to helping the lives of New York sickest children.
summary: The Friends of St. Mary’s (FOSM) committee is a network of passionate professionals who are committed to enriching the lives of St. Mary’s Kids and their families through fundraising, advocacy, leadership and volunteering.
title: St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children

content_id:
Project Hope Charities Food Pantry serves over 8,000 persons monthly. We need consistent volunteers to enable us to meet our growing demand. The community is in need. Most of our clients cannot effectively provide food for themselves and their family even though they have jobs. It is just not enough to meet their needs. We live in a city where the rent keeps going up and they have to choose between food and other basic necessities. Our job is to ensure they can eat and survive.

We receive deliveries on a daily basis and distribute on to the community on Saturdays.
summary: We are seeking volunteers to join our Food pantry team.
title: Project Hope Charities Inc.

The Auxiliary works in collaboration with hospital administration to advance the quality of patient care services. content_id:
Volunteers serve breakfast to the elderly at our Senior Program! Some of the most vulnerable New Yorkers are senior citizens. Be on the front lines in the fight against hunger at our Community Kitchen in West Harlem, where you'll help serve fresh meals and be a friendly face for members of our senior program. You’ll also help clean up after breakfast.

 

Anyone preparing food should remove watches, rings, bracelets and all other jewelry on their arms or hands, as well as long earrings or necklaces, while preparing food. Jewelry can fall into the food and pose a health hazard. Medical alert bracelets or a smooth ring such as a wedding band are allowed. 

 

Please Note: While we have a shared locker, please leave all valuables at home.
summary: Are you looking to be on the front lines in the fight against hunger? In our Community Kitchen you can prepare, cook and serve food to our clients. In our Pantry you can assist clients as they shop for food and restock the pantry throughout the day.

content_id:
As the city's major hunger relief organization, Food Bank distributes more than 74 million pounds of food every year — providing 400,000 free meals per day to New Yorkers in need.
 
70 volunteers are needed on a daily basis to repack over one million pounds of food every year. Join us for this exciting project directly benefiting our Member Agencies and clients across the city. You can provide vital help to us at our highest need project by sorting donated and bulk items into boxes of specific categories and weights at our Food Distribution Center. Boxes are then shipped directly to our network food pantries and community kitchens throughout the five boroughs.
 

Please refrain from wearing jewelry, except for wedding bands.


Please Note: This project is best for groups.
summary: Feeling like a wizard behind the curtain? Work your magic at one  of our repack projects. You can break down donations of 500 pounds or more, then sort and repack the food into boxes that will be shipped out to organizations all over New York City.
title: Food Bank For New York City

Compile or develop materials to submit for grant.
Develop and maintain media contact lists.
Develop strategies to encourage new or increased contributions.

Secure commitments of participation or donation from individuals or corporate donors.

Create or update donor databases.
Direct or coordinate web-based fundraising activities, such as online auctions.
Plan and direct special events for fundraising, such as silent auctions, dances, golf events, or walks.
Solicit cash or in-kind donations or sponsorships from individual, business, or government donors.
Conduct research to identify the goals, net worth, history of charitable donations, or other data related to potential donors, potential investors, or general donor markets.
Secure speakers for charitable events, community meetings, or conferences to increase awareness of charitable and nonprofit, causes. 
Write and send letters of thanks to donors.

requirements:
Required:

  • Consistent availability on Tuesday and/or Thursday from 10:00am to 12:00pm

  • Charismatic, dynamic, and interactive instruction methods

  • Motivated to help students achieve their goals

  • Competent in and respectful of cultural differences

Bonus Points:

  • Students enrolled in a CELTA, TESOL, or TEFL program or retired teachers

  • Passionate about advancing immigrant rights

  • Fluency or bilingualism in another language (especially Arabic, Spanish, and Bengali)

Compensation: Unpaid

Hours: 2-4 hours per week; not flexible

To apply, please submit a cover letter and resume to volunteer@cianainc.org. Or find out more about us on our social media or website and let’s chat: @cianainc or www.cianainc.org
content_id:
You are a charismatic teacher or tutor of the English language with a passion for teaching ESL or ESOL students. You want to work closely with a small group of students to help them reach their reading, writing, and speaking goals. Sound like you? Good!

CIANA is looking for a volunteer ESL instructor to teach once or twice per week. Our classes are typically composed of 10-20 students whose English proficiency ranges from beginner to intermediate. You must be comfortable managing a diverse group of students and facilitating fun and interactive activities.

Description:

The Center for the Integration & Advancement of New Americans (CIANA) is a social services organization that works to integrate new immigrants from South Asia, the Middle East, North Africa, and Latin America into the socio-economic and civic life of American society while maintaining pride in their cultural heritage.

Responsibilities:

  • Write and deliver English lessons that incorporate reading, writing, speaking, and listening components based on a curriculum

  • Facilitate lessons on life skills and practical English in a fun and accessible way

  • Collaborate with other ESL teachers on lesson development and execution

  • Assist in tracking student needs and progress
summary: CIANA is looking for an ESL instructor to teach once or twice per week. Our classes are typically composed of 10-20 students whose English proficiency ranges from beginner to intermediate. You must be comfortable managing a diverse group of students and facilitating fun and interactive activities.
title: Center for the Integration and Advancement of New Americans

requirements:

  • Consistent availability on Monday and/or Wednesday from 10:00am to 12:00pm

  • Charismatic, dynamic, and interactive instruction methods

Bonus Points:

  • Retirees are welcome

  • Interest in civics, government, or US history

  • Fluency or bilingualism in another language (especially Arabic, Spanish, and Bengali)

CIANA is looking for a volunteer civics instructor to teach once or twice per week. Our classes are typically composed of 10-20 students whose English proficiency ranges from beginner to intermediate who are studying to take their US citizenship exam. You must be comfortable managing a diverse group of students and facilitating fun and interactive activities.

Description:

The Center for the Integration & Advancement of New Americans (CIANA) is a social services organization that works to integrate new immigrants from South Asia, the Middle East, North Africa, and Latin America into the socio-economic and civic life of American society while maintaining pride in their cultural heritage.

Responsibilities:

  • Write and deliver civics lessons to prepare students for naturalization interview based on a curriculum

  • Facilitate lessons in a fun and accessible way while enhancing their English reading, writing, speaking, and listening

  • Collaborate with other civics teachers on lesson development and execution

  • Assist in tracking student needs and progress
summary: CIANA is looking for a civics instructor to teach once or twice per week. Our classes are typically composed of 10-20 students whose English proficiency ranges from beginner to intermediate who are studying to take their US citizenship exam.

Volunteers are crucial to the success of an event. They help things run smoothly and ensure that every guest has a wonderful experience. Throughout the year, the Staten Island Museum offers engaging public programs and special events, many of which require a lot of volunteer support.  We are building a Special Events team comprised of volunteers who will bring their energy and enthusiasm to every special event assignment. 


Volunteer Job Responsibilities include:

*Event Set-up & Breakdown
*Greeting and Directing Guests
*Check In
*Assisting with instructor led activities
*Housekeeping and facilities support
*Other event related tasks as needed

The Museum’s operating hours are Wednesday- Sunday 11:00am-5:00pm
Public programs generally occur on Saturdays and Sundays regularly and Thursday evenings as per the calendar schedule.  Flexibility is appreciated.


Volunteers will work with the following departments:

*Visitor Services
*Programs
*Development
*Facilities
summary:
Staten Island Museum Special Event Volunteers…Make Our Events Amazing! 

Maybe you have event production experience, have a passion for logistics, enjoy working with the public and having fun.  If that sounds like you, then the Staten Island Museum needs your support!
title: Staten Island Museum

opportunity_id: Volunteer (with Stipend) to Fight Food Waste and Hunger on Friday Afternoons!
content_id:
Volunteer Food Rescuers help us transport food from our food donor partners to local homeless shelters, soup kitchens, and other human service agencies in our communities. Each food rescue event can be done on foot, and each event typically takes less than an hour. That means that less than a mile of walking and an hour of your time can reduce food waste and provide meals to those who need it most!

We are especially seeking passionate and committed leaders who are willing to take on the role of Core Rescuer and lead the same 5 food rescue events on a weekly, recurring basis! Core Rescuers receive compensation of $63.50 on a bi-weekly basis, meaning you will receive the equivalent of an unlimited monthly MetroCard to reimburse you for your travels around the city!
summary:
Did you know 40% of food in the USA is wasted?

Did you know 1 and 7 Americans are food insecure?

Did you know YOU can help?

Join Rescuing Leftover Cuisine and provide a reliable food rescue service by fostering community connections in order to reduce food waste and food insecurity in NYC!
title: Rescuing Leftover Cuisine

requirements:
Fosters are sought who will agree to provide the home care, food and medicine recommended and/or provided by Place For Cats and our veterinarians.  All medical care and medicine is provided. Fosters normally agree to provide the recommended food and litter. Place For Cats provides food for kitties with extra special food requirements. 

Ideally, the foster has had experience with pets and can administer basic medication, such as oral antibiotics and/or eye ointments. Most people can be taught how to do this if they have had no prior experience. All fosters are asked to complete and sign our basic fostering application which appears on our website.
content_id: Place For Cats seeks foster moms and dads for our rescued felines. The more fosters, the more cats that can be saved.  Because the fosters frequently end up adopting their wards, new fosters are always needed as new rescues arrive. Most of the cats rescued by Place For Cats come from Animal Care Centers' nightly At Risk lists ("death lists"). We save animals that NYC would euthanize due to a broken limb that requires six weeks of confiinement, or an upper respiratory illness ("kitty cold") that requires a couple weeks of antibiotics. Each rescue is placed with a loving foster who has the time and ability to care for the kitty while the wound heals or the ailment subsides.  When the feline is all better, he/she goes on Place For Cats' adoption roster and a purrrrmanent loving home is found.
summary: Place For Cats operates via a network of foster homes. Fostering periods usually run from a couple weeks to several months.  Medical care costs are provided by Place For Cats.
title: Place For Cats, Inc.

content_id:
Van Cortlandt Park Conservancy’s mission is to sustain and enhance the park as a vibrant destination for recreation, leisure and the enjoyment of natural landscapes.

Van Cortlandt Park Conservancy (VCPC), a 501(c)3 organization, was incorporated in 2009 as a public/private partnership with NYC Parks. Modeled after successful non-profit organizations that have shepherded the transformation of Central Park and Prospect Park, VCPC provides educational and cultural programming as well as staffing to enhance the Park’s woodlands, fields, playgrounds, and ball fields. Van Cortlandt Park, serving an estimated 2.5 million people annually, is the third largest park in New York City—a “living classroom” and a quality-of-life hub in the Bronx.

Volunteers will work closely with the Special Events Coordinator and with the Volunteer Coordinator to create and translate written material. For example: monthly/weekly flyers, e-blast messages and brochures.
summary: The Van Cortlandt Park Conservancy is seeking a bilingual volunteer who can translate English documents into Spanish. Flexible schedule available.
title: Van Cortlandt Park Conservancy

opportunity_id: GallopNYC: Volunteer with HORSES to help people with Disabilities in New York City
content_id:
Join GallopNYC's volunteer team.

Therapeutic horsemanship teaches the skills of horseback riding and horse knowledge to build developmental, emotional, social, and physical skills for each individual rider. Under the direction of a PATH International certiﬁed instructor, supported by trained volunteers, each rider progressively acquires riding skills and measurable improvements in life skills. Through weekly sessions, we help riders walk, talk, learn and have FUN! We also oﬀer hippotherapy services.Therapeutic horsemanship means more than just learning to ride a horse – it means building a bond with a horse, learning to care for a horse, understanding how horses perceive the world and respond to people, and ultimately being a leader to a horse.

Volunteer Duties:

  • Side Walking: Assist the instructor during therapeutic riding sessions by working directly with the riders. Act as an intermediary between the rider and instructor by assisting the rider in carrying out the instructor’s directions.

    • Help prepare riders for lessons

    • Assist with rider support during mounting and dismounting

    • Walk (and jog) next to the rider throughout the class and provide physical support as necessary

    • Help the rider follow directions given by the instructor

  • Lead Walking: Volunteer will lead horses during therapeutic riding classes, working with a group of side-walkers, keeping primary focus on assigned horse (and not the rider) while maintaining communication with team.

    • Executes directions of the instructor during therapeutic riding sessions

    • Depending on site, will bring horses in and out of arena

*Note: No experience necessary. We provide all required training.

How do I start?

  • Individual: Visit our volunteer portal at volunteer.gallopnyc.org

  • Group: Contact our volunteer management team at volunteer@gallopnyc.org or 646.233.4507

Questions?

volunteer@gallopnyc.org or 646.233.4507
summary: GallopNYC is a non-proﬁt organization based in New York City that oﬀers therapeutic horsemanship programs to children and adults with disabilities.
title: GallopNYC Therapeutic Horseback Riding Program

Reports to: Program Director      

Department: Youth Development

Location: Carey Gardens Cornerstone Community Center- Carey Gardens 2315 Surf Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11224

General Function: A good mentor can change a young person’s life. Mentors meet with students and engage in discussions and activities which would be conducive to the young person’s development. We expect mentees to benefit in the areas of education, health and civic engagement. The goal is to build a trusting relationship and encourage students to succeed, overcome obstacles, meet goals and reach their greatest potential.

Specific Duties:

  • Lead weekly activities that foster the importance of educational success and healthy lifestyle skills for youth.
  • Accompany mentees to enrichment activities to develop a supportive relationship.
  • Demonstrate the importance of community involvement to help mentees understand the value of giving back.
  • Maintain a current record of all documents associated to mentoring.
  • Attend supervisory meetings and trainings to learn about updates and procedures.
  • Partake in community service events that are held by the community center.

Desired Attributes:

  • Mentors must be 21 years old or older to participate
  • Must have received a High School Diploma or GED
  • Must be willing to complete a background screening (SCR, SEL clearance  and criminal history)
  • Experience in conflict resolution and youth supervision
  • Passionate about youth advocacy and being a positive role model for youth  

Time Commitment: Volunteers will be expected to have availability on Tuesday evenings for 2 hours between 7:00 pm – 9:00pm. Additional arrangements can be made to fit a mentor’s schedule.

Support: Training for this position will be provided from the Program Director who will be a dedicated liaison for mentors. In addition, mentors will receive DYCD training resources throughout the duration of this opportunity.

Benefits: This opportunity is best suited for individuals that want more experience working with youth in the nonprofit sector. We are looking for a community leader who understands that community engagement has a large impact on a youth’s life. . The program will provide on occasion food, swag, free trips with students and Metrocards for traveling.

To apply: Email D’ Netra Mincey dmincey@wearebcs.org  Phone: 718-758-5068
summary: Do you like working with youth? Come volunteer at Brooklyn Community Services to change a young man's life for the better.  This mentoring opportunity will be a meaningful experience that you will remember for a lifetime.
title: Brooklyn Community Services

requirements:
• Sincere desire to be personally involved with another person to help him or her achieve personal and career goals;

  • Ability to communicate with young adults openly and nonjudgmentally;

  • Strong listening skills;

  • Ability to establish a relationship based on equal responsibility and respect;

  • Interest in needs and concerns of persons with internal and external barriers to steady employment;

  • Experience in healthcare;

  • Practical problem-solving skills and ability to suggest options and alternatives; and

  • Sensitivity to persons of different educational, economic, cultural or racial backgrounds.
content_id:
Mentoring is a structured and trusting relationship that brings young people together with caring individuals who offer guidance, support, and encouragement aimed at developing the competence and character of a mentee. St. Nicks Alliance mentors serve as part of our team that works to provide career assistance to young adults. Mentors commit to spend at least 2 hours per month with the young adults for eleven months. Mentors spend this weekly time simply being adult friends to the young adult (mentee). Not a parent, not a therapist, not a preacher. Rather, a team of adult friends that invest their time listening, building trust, establishing relationship, supporting, guiding and through the course of the year share their passion for healthcare.

Responsibilities/Commitment:

St. Nicks Alliance mentors participate in the following areas:

  • 2–4 hours/month of quality time spent with the mentee;
  • All mentor trainings;
  • Group mentor–mentee activities; and
  • Annual Mentoring Celebration.

Supervision/Support Schedule:

  • Monthly phone meetings with program coordinator;
  • Monthly reporting to the program coordinator; and
  • Monthly or bimonthly team meetings regarding progress of youth.

Mentor Expectations

  • Provide candid and open conversations
  • LISTEN! Helping create a plan and holding the mentee accountable to their decisions
  • Empower the mentee to succeed and take risk
  • Challenge (and then support) the mentee
  • Work with the mentee to develop goals and outcomes
  • Be open to their own personal growth that may appear during process
  • Commit to the relationship with consistent communication
  • Set the mentee up for success

FAQs

Q: What is mentoring?

Mentoring is a structured and trusting relationship that brings young people together with caring individuals who offer guidance, support, and encouragement aimed at developing the competence and character of a mentee.

Q: How long has the CNA Mentor Program been in existence?

This is a pilot program to support our CAN Training beyond skills development.  Our CNA program first launched in October of 2017.  Each participant in our 2nd CNA cohort will be matched with an industry mentor with the goal of enhancing the career pathway development for the mentee. 

Q: Are there any requirements to be a mentee?

Your mentee is a young adult interested in healthcare between the ages of 17-24 years old that is participating in a CAN Training Program funded by DYCD at St. Nicks Alliance.

Q: Are there any requirements to be a mentor?

  • Sincere desire to be personally involved with another person to help him or her achieve personal and career goals;
  • Ability to communicate with young adults openly and nonjudgmentally;
  • Strong listening skills;
  • Ability to establish a relationship based on equal responsibility and respect;
  • Interest in needs and concerns of persons with internal and external barriers to steady employment;
  • Practical problem-solving skills and ability to suggest options and alternatives; and
  • Sensitivity to persons of different educational, economic, cultural or racial backgrounds.

Q: Where will the mentoring take place?

The CNA Mentor Program will take place for the most part on-location at St Nicks Alliance Workforce Development Center located at 790 Broadway, 2nd Floor, Brooklyn, NY, 11206. There will be events outside of the office, as well.

Q: What if I am not able to meet one week?

As this program requires accountability at all levels from everyone involved, if you are unable to meet one week you would contact and coordinate with your mentee, as well as e-mailing the program coordinator. Contact information will be distributed upon the launch of the program.

Q: What is the role of a Mentor?

  • Help ensure that their mentee has a successful transition into employment and/or post-secondary education;
  • Act as a confidential and trusted advisor;
  • Be a teacher and coach to the mentee;
  • Serve as a resource and repository of information;
  • Partner with St. Nicks Alliance staff to problem-solve challenges and questions that may arise including performance pitfalls;
  • Assist in purposeful networking; and
  • Provide thought and guidance on leading through change.

Q: Will I be trained?

Yes, you will be trained. Additional training will be provided upon request.

Q: What is the ongoing commitment required of trained mentors?

The mentor program will run from April 2019 –February 2020. The mentor is expected to spend a minimum of 2 hours per month with the mentee.

Q: Why should I volunteer my services as a mentor?   

It is a rewarding opportunity to share your career development progression and provide advice to a young adult as they embark on their own career pathway allowing them to stay in the community they were raised in and build a pathway to economic sustainability. 

Q: How will I be matched?

After reviewing the applications detailing personal information and conducting individual interviews to attain additional information, the program coordinator matches a student with a mentor based on individual profiles, family/cultural backgrounds, and/or personal and career interests.

Q: What happens at the end of the mentorship program? Can I continue my mentorship relationship?

Yes. Continued relationships are encouraged, but not a required after the program has ended.

Additional questions?

2018 CNA Partners

Manhattan Institute

NYC Department of Youth & Community Development

content_id:
NYC Service, a division of the Office of the Mayor, promotes volunteerism, engages New Yorkers in service, builds volunteer capacity and mobilizes the power of volunteers and national service members to impact New York City’s greatest needs. Our vision is to inspire and empower all New Yorkers to volunteer and serve NYC and each other.

Position Overview: NYC Service Year is a citywide movement led by the NYC Service Year Leadership Council to promote, sustain, and grow service year programming in NYC, which engages young adults in service to their city, empowering their individual growth and civic leadership while delivering measurable change in key City priorities such as Education, Economic Opportunity, and Environment/Health. NYC Service Year is seeking a Developer to launch Phase II of the existing domorebemore.nyc site with an internal portal that will house an application exchange, data repository, and calendar. The portal will need to be secure enough to store PII at government standards. Our website, domorebemore.nyc is our platform to connect service year programming across the city and achieve this mission. Phase I of domorebemore.nyc has already been launched and is currently being used to share announcements, events, and public member information.

This is an unpaid volunteer position.

Key Responsibilities: The NYC Service Year Developer will help:

  • Design a Wordpress-compatible database to input, sort, and organize a range of data types
  • Ensure data privacy and government compliance standards for storage/access
  • Create a user login portal with roles of varying levels of access
  • Document platform design and functionality for sustainable site management by NYC Service after completion of the project
  • Roll-out Phase II refresh of main website, pending progress of database development

Location: This is a remote opportunity, but NYC-based applicants are preferred.

Qualifications: Extensive web design and development experience. Experience using WordPress and familiarity with database design concepts. Knowledge of cloud-based systems and databases preferred.

Time Commitment: The desired start date is January 2019. The position is expected to be 2-3 months in duration, 20-25 hours/month.

Volunteer Supervisor: The position will report directly to the NYC Service Year Support Coordinator.

Training/Support Provided: The NYC Service Year Developer will receive an NYC Service orientation and have ongoing bi weekly/monthly or as needed check-ins with their supervisor for the duration of the project.

Benefits: The NYC Service Year Developer will receive experience and expertise working in local government, as well as a letter of recommendation and proof of service upon completion
summary: NYC Service, a division of the Office of the Mayor, promotes volunteerism, engages New Yorkers in service, builds volunteer capacity and mobilizes the power of volunteers and national service members to impact New York City’s greatest needs.
title: NYC Service

content_id:
Top Honors (TH) is a free math tutoring program serving NYC middle school students (5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th graders) who struggle with math.

Top Honors seeks volunteers who can make the same weekly commitment to one of these time slots from October - May. School holidays are observed, which averages out to be 2-3 Saturdays per month.

Our tutors are NYC professionals looking for a meaningful, long-term, weekend volunteer experience. Volunteers are compassionate, engaging, communicative, patient, and comfortable with basic middle school math concepts. You should be comfortable working fairly autonomously within the structure of our program. We love people who can run with things and ask questions.
summary: Tutor math and mentor NYC middle school students in the Lower East Side on Saturday mornings, from October 2019 through May 2020!
title: Top Honors, Inc.

A Free Bird is a 501(C)(3) non-profit organization based in New York City. Our focus is to provide children, ages 4-18 who are patients or survivors of juvenile cancer, the opportunity to explore their artistic passions and give them the strength to fight their disease. We believe that artistic expression is critical for healing! A Free Bird supports children affected by cancer in their exploration of art, music, acting, poetry, writing, singing and any other artistic passion they may have.

After a very incredible and successful year and in order to help as many kids as possible we are seeking a highly skilled volunteer/intern fundraiser for the new year 2019. Your passion and dedication will directly lead to more young people getting the arts opportunities they deserve.

Overall Responsibilities:

Assisting Fundraising Coordinator/VP of Fundraising with any job-related task for Fundraising assistant. Consisting of, but not limited to:

  • Scheduling appointments for Fundraising Coordinator.
  • Assisting in reaching out to donors and supporters for companies.
  • Researching information
  • Creating documents
  • Sending emails
  • Setting up meetings with other department heads
  • Reaching out to other departments for information

  • Help develop other lists of potential donors where the names are known but not contact information.
  • Internet searching
  • Keeping consistent relations with donors and future donors/sponsors.
  • Assists in the development of Brochures, flyers, posters, etc.
  • Must support and maintain mission goal and statement of organization.
  • Meet at least once per week meet with Fundraising Coordinator.

Competencies:

  • Understanding of Google Docs
  • Understanding of Microsoft Office, PowerPoint, Excel, Word, etc.
  • Friendly phone personality, etiquette on being able to write emails.
  • Highly organized.
  • Experience with Internet Searching.
  • Ability to multitask and help manage a few projects at once.

opportunity_id: Women Empowering Women : Bigs & Littles NYC's New Initiative!
content_id:
In 2019, Bigs & Littles NYC is piloting "Mentoring Moms", a women empowered program to help strengthen youth outcomes and help moms/guardians increase their ability to accomplish personal goals around academic and/or career, strengthening relationships and incorporating a healthier lifestyle for themselves and their families.

If you are a woman who is interested in being a friend, guide and a support to a mother/guardian of a child in our Community-Based Mentoring Program, then this is the right volunteer opportunity for you!

Join a community who uplifts NYC families!

The Match:

  • The Mentoring Moms program will follow a "community based" model, which provides our matches with the opportunity to participate in a 1:1 relationship. Mentoring Mom and Mentor will meet independently and within the community at large.
  • Overall, there is a 4-hour minimum monthly contact between in-person and phone/email/text, for a minimum of one year.
  • Matches will build and maintain their relationship by engaging in weekly phone/email/text contact.
  • Mentoring Mom will also meet with their Mentor 1-2 times a month, for a minimum of one year.

Requirements for Bigs (Volunteer Mentor):

  • Must be at least 21 years old
  • Live within the NYC Metropolitan area
  • Have a schedule conducive to meet for outings, 1-2 times month, for one year
  • Maintain weekly contact with Mentoring Mom to help build a relationship
  • Maintain communication with Program Manager
  • Participate in specialized programming
  • Interested in working with a Mentoring Mom
  • Bigs are responsible for financing all match outings. The agency encourages low-cost activities to both limit the volunteer’s expenses AND to avoid setting unrealistic expectations.

Interested? Contact us:

  • On the internet: bigsnyc.org/volunteer
  • On the phone: 212-475-3291 x211
  • On social media: Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram

Mentoring not a good fit right now? Get in touch to learn how you can support us with volunteer recruitment, donor cultivation, and other engagement opportunities at Bigs & Littles NYC.
summary: Bigs and Littles NYC is excited to announce the Women Empowering Women Initiative! If you are a woman who is interested in being a friend, guide and a support to a mother/guardian of a child in our Community-Based Mentoring Program, then this is the right volunteer opportunity for you!
title: Bigs & Littles NYC Mentoring

requirements: UHAB is looking for youth ages 14 to 24 with an interest in affordable housing and oral history. Some personal connection to co-ops is preferred but not necessary.
opportunity_id: Cooperatives and Homesteading Oral History Project
content_id:
Affordable, limited-equity HDFC co-ops have a unique history and place in the landscape of New York City’s housing. There are about 1,100 HDFC co-ops in New York City today. These co-ops have taken different legal paths to become co-ops since the 1970s.

Some HDFCs started as occupied buildings abandoned by the landlords. Tenants were able to advocate for themselves through the city’s Tenant Interim Lease (TIL) program and, usually after years of training and practice in self-management, became cooperative owners. Others started out as vacant buildings, abandoned many years before. City residents in need of affordable housing began rebuilding some of these, turning crumbling structures into habitable homes through their own labor and later becoming co-op owners as well.

The Urban Homesteading Assistance Board (UHAB) was founded in 1973 to help residents take control of their housing through the cooperative model. Our organization has accumulated many pieces of history from the co-ops we’ve assisted throughout the years. As affordable housing becomes a more crucial issue in New York City than ever, we are now working to keep the memory of these co-ops’ struggle for survival and self-determination alive through the collection of oral histories.

This is an opportunity for youth to learn firsthand about an important and under-publicized piece of our city’s history, develop interviewing and primary source research skills, and contribute to a non-profit organization’s effort to create a living oral history archive. Participating students should have an active interest in affordable housing and if possible some connection to affordable housing co-ops.

Students will receive training on affordable housing, HDFCs, and collecting oral history. We will work with students to identify and recruit interviewees. Interviews will be used to inform ongoing UHAB projects, such as an exhibition on the history of homesteading and HDFC co-ops, and an illustrated book. Students will also have the chance to create a write-up or other project based on their findings. This position involves travel.
summary: This position is a research position for youth interested in the history of affordable housing in New York City.
title: UHAB

requirements: UHAB is looking for youth (ages 14-24) with an interest in organizing and tenants' rights. Students who live or go to school in Crown Heights are especially encouraged to apply.
content_id:
UHAB’s Organizing department helps renters in Brooklyn and Manhattan create strong tenant associations to deter displacement and hold landlords accountable for improving living conditions. UHAB has worked to prevent the unnecessary evictions of families in rent-stabilized buildings by supporting the Crown Heights Tenant Union, a collective of tenant associations in the neighborhood. We hope to engage youth in this work during the spring semester of 2019.

The Youth Tenant Organizing Program will train participants in the following:
• New York State housing rights
• Researching buildings
• Successful door knocking practices
• Facilitation of tenant meetings

After completing the training, students can use their required community service hours towards developing their own tenant association and encouraging them to fight for better services or assist in our outreach to buildings in Crown Heights. This experience will help train future leaders to fight for housing justice in their communities. Priority given to students who live or go to school in the Crown Heights area.
summary: This position will train youth in basic organizing skills, such as doorknocking and meeting facilitation.
title: UHAB

requirements:
• I want to mentor high-potential, low-income, first-generation college students in their personal and professional development.
  • I am passionate about giving back to the community.
  • I am available to attend career development workshops 1-2 Saturdays per month for 2 years.
  • I am a college graduate with 3+ years of work experience, willing to share my industry expertise and network.
opportunity_id: Pay it Forward! Be a Mentor Coach with America Needs You!
content_id:
America Needs You (ANY) helps outstanding, low-income, first-generation college students ("Fellows") select, secure, and succeed in their careers. The Fellows Program is an intensive two year mentoring and training program where Fellows are matched one-on-one with highly-accomplished professional Mentor Coaches dedicated to their personal and professional growth.

Why: First-generation college students, first in their family to go to college, drop out at 5 times the rate of their peer group - only 11% graduate (Pell Institute, 2011).

Benefits of the Mentor Coach Experience:

  • Develop a one-on-one mentoring relationship with your Fellow,and help them achieve their career ambitions.
  • Serve as a role model and resource for your class of 100 Mentor Coach/Fellow pairs.
  • Network with highly accomplished professionals from a variety of industries
  • Gain access to exclusive professional development and social events

Workshop Experience:

  • Workshops are held on Saturdays throughout Manhattan.
  • Year One workshops occur bi-weekly and typically run from 10:30 A.M. to 4:00 P.M, followed by optional volunteer-led social events.
  • Year Two workshops occur monthly and are shorter with more industry and skill-specific events tailored to our Fellows' needs and interests.
  • Curriculum includes professional development topics such as resumes and cover letters, elevator pitches, mock interviews, networking, professional etiquette, and more.

Location: New York, Jersey City, Chicago 

To Apply: www.americaneedsyou.org/mentors-apply

Next Steps:

Join our growing team of volunteers! For more information, please visit www.americaneedsyou.org or contact volunteers@americaneedsyou.org with any questions.
summary: The Fellows Program is an intensive two year mentoring and training program where Fellows are matched one-on-one with highly-accomplished professional Mentor Coaches dedicated to their personal and professional growth. We need mentor coaches for New York, Jersey City, and Chicago!
title: America Needs You

requirements: The All Stars Project Talented Volunteers welcomes all New Yorkers and offers activities for all people, from young or old to highly skilled or newly curious. The one requirement is to support our mission, finding it in all volunteer activities. Okay, a second — have fun!
content_id: The All Stars Project, a six-city national nonprofit, built itself with volunteerism and that hasn't changed. Within six programs volunteers run an off-off Broadway theater; perform community outreach; provide office support; staff special events; run tech operations, and more. While some volunteers contribute often and some during special events, all help build the All Stars' mission: to transform the lives of youth and poor communities using the developmental power of performance, in partnership with caring adults.
summary: Join hundreds of other Talented Volunteers and support our six dynamic programs focused on Afterschool Development.
title: All Stars Project

requirements:
• You need to be trained. In order to provide support in the event of an emergency—or even in a non-emergency situation—you need to have the proper training and licensing. Learn more about the ARRL Emergency Communications Training course.
     
  • You need to be equipped with sustaining skills. What if when you get to a location, there is no food and the sleeping conditions are undesirable? Before you leave on your assignment, you need to make sure you have coping skills that enable you to be able to do your job operating under the conditions you are assigned to—from hardship conditions to making sure you’re able to work the equipment.
     
  • You need to prepare your family for your absence. When you leave home and head for a disaster area, your family has to be both physically and mentally able to cope. After a disaster, when a volunteer comes home, he or she can be confronted by some mental health issues, for which there are several resources. Many volunteers experience everything from fatigue or exhaustion to depression.

requirements:

Must be proficient in Quickbooks and MS Excel.

Individual must have ability to work independently with minimal supervision, as well as possess leadership abilities to train volunteer junior staff
content_id:
A Free Bird is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization based in New York City. Our focus is to provide children, ages 4-18 who are patients or survivors of juvenile cancer, the opportunity to explore their artistic passions and give them the strength to fight their disease. We believe that artistic expression is critical for healing! A Free Bird supports children affected by cancer in their exploration of art, music, acting, poetry, writing, singing and any other artistic passion they may have.

We are seeking a part time bookkeeper with a minimum of 5 years’ experience in non-profit accounting. You must be proficient in Quickbooks and MS Excel. 

Duties include the following: 

  • Perform monthly close process, including importing banking information into Quickbooks and recording accounting transactions.
  • Perform balance sheet and profit & loss account reconciliations including coding journal entries.
  • Maintain detail analysis of contributions income and program expenses.
  • Assist with ad hoc projects as required by management. 

Individual must have ability to work independently with minimal supervision, as well as possess leadership abilities to train volunteer junior staff.

AFB is open Tuesday-Thursday from 10:30 AM to 6:00 PM.
summary: We are seeking a part time bookkeeper with minimum 5 years’ experience in non-profit accounting. You must be proficient in Quickbooks and MS Excel.

requirements:
About Volunteering With I Challenge Myself:

  • Hours are flexible Mon-Fri and can be adapted to fit your schedule

Background and Desired Experience:

  • A passion and understanding for the importance of mind-body-spirit connection

  • The ability to move from abstract to concrete levels of understanding and communication

content_id:
Since February 2005, I Challenge Myself has provided over 2300 public high school students to strengthen their bodies, minds and spirit through our three programs: 4toFIT, Cycling Smarts and the College Bike Tour.  Each of these programs provide students with self and team fitness challenges (a 100-miles 1-day bike tour, strength and cardio circuits and 400+ mile 7-day bike tour of colleges in upstate NY) that help them connect with their inner strength and build physical and mental resilience in life and prepare for college and the workforce.

We are seeking a highly skilled volunteer/intern fundraiser to help us reach our 2019/20 fundraising goals. Your passion and dedication will directly lead to more high school students getting the fitness, college and career readiness opportunities they deserve.

Responsibilities:

  • Assist Executive Director to create and manage marketing related to fundraising initiatives for a nonprofit organization that is diversifying its revenue by increasing funding from individuals, events (in person/crowdfunding) and corporations.
  • Assist with production of marketing materials used to secure corporate sponsorships, major gifts and in-kind resources from corporations, individual donors and philanthropic foundations and ticket sales
  • Draft and disseminate the Organization’s quarterly e-newsletter via Campaign Monitor, which includes producing photos and content
summary: Are you ready to use your awesome fundraising skills to help NYC high school students tap into their inner strength through fitness and cycling challenges? I Challenge Myself needs you to help us shatter our 2019 fundraising goals to support program expansion in 2019-20.
title: I Challenge Myself

Since February 2005, I Challenge Myself has provided over 2300 public high school students to strengthen their bodies, minds and spirit through our three programs: 4toFIT, Cycling Smarts and the College Bike Tour.  Each of these programs provide students with self and team fitness challenges (a 100-miles 1-day bike tour, strength and cardio circuits and 400+ mile 7-day bike tour of colleges in upstate NY) that help them connect with their inner strength and build physical and mental resilience in life and prepare for college and the workforce.

Overview:
The non-profit development associate will work closely with I Challenge Myself’s Executive Director in building organizational capacity in support of I Challenge Myself’s youth development programs, which use fitness and cycling a tool to help youth . content_id:
We invite you to be part of the team of 1,500 volunteer licensed medical professionals who will provide medical expertise to 50,000 runners at the 2019 TCS New York City Marathon on November 3rd. You will meet great people, gain experience with event medicine, and be a part of the world’s largest marathon. You must be able to attend a medical orientation in advance of the event and to stay for the full duration of your assignment.

We are looking for Attending, Fellow and MR Physicians who are able to rapidly assess and treat medical conditions ranging from minor to life threatening. Proof of a valid medical license and board certification is required. Your license and certification must be valid through race day. 

Volunteers are accepted on the rolling basis. You will be notified when your profile is complete. All medical volunteers receive a TCS NYC Marathon windbreaker jacket to wear on race day, a T-Shirt, a commemorative volunteer lapel pin, a certificate of appreciation, and a letter of community service

To learn more about medical positions and opportunities, please visit: https://www.tcsnycmarathon.org/volunteers/opportunities or email medical@nyrr.org.

opportunity_id: Volunteers for Latin American Arts Events and Exchanges
content_id: We are looking for volunteers who are interested in supporting PAMAR in a variety of tasks, depending on what is needed at the moment. Tasks include the maintenance of our social media accounts, assistance with preparing events, finding new collaborators, fundraising, marketing, distributing and mailing brochures, and networking. PAMAR organizes a variety of events each year, the biggest of them being Latin American Cultural Week (LACW) -- > http://www.lacw.net/calendar.php In 2018, we produced and co-produced 30 events all over Manhattan with more than 8000 guests. In 2019, we are planning to divide LACW into 3 or 4 different weeks to maximize our outreach. During these events, we are always happy to have helping hands at the receptions and box offices, setting up the venues and representing PAMAR by handing out business cards and providing guests with information, answering questions etc. In February, we opened a new artist residency Tlacopac in Mexico City, to provide artists from all kinds of backgrounds with a unique and individual retreat opportunity to develop their art. As a volunteer, you would assist in reviewing and coordinating applications and ensuring that everything is perfectly prepared for each arriving guest at the residency. If you have other specific skills that would like to use to support us, for example in web design, media outreach or marketing campaigns, just reach out us!
summary: Volunteers needed for a variety of ongoing tasks: Organization of conferences, concerts, and exhibitions; Maintenance of social media accounts, building partnerships with collaborators, fundraising, marketing, planning artist residencies, distributing and mailing brochures, and networking.

opportunity_id: Greeter-Guide Volunteering at Washington Square Park
content_id:
About the Program

The Washington Square Park Conservancy (WSPC) is a 501(c)3 not for profit organization working with the New York City Parks Department and neighborhood groups to ensure that Washington Square Park continues as a diverse and historical urban green space through engaging volunteers and raising funds to help keep the park clean, safe, and beautiful.

WSPC is accepting new volunteers into its Greeter-Tour Program, a program that interacts with Park users, helping them learn about the exciting horticulture, history, events, and culture that the Park has to offer. From our resident hawks to the coveted Arch, the Park has many stories to be told!

Volunteer Greeter-Guide Description

WSPC is seeking committed volunteers to donate their time and expertise for this free Park program. The WSPC Greeter-Tour Program provides an opportunity for interested volunteers to become an official Washington Square Park Docent.

This program runs during the warmer months. Docents will be expected to work a minimum of 2 shifts per month, and each shift will last 3 hours (totaling 6 hours per month). Shifts will be on Saturdays and Sundays from 11am to 2pm. Greeters will provide information about the Park and the Conservancy to visitors during their shift. Volunteers will work in a team of their fellow volunteers. Once docents have completed the greeter orientation program, they can continue their training to become a WSP tour guide.

Volunteers must attend and participate in the program’s orientation, as well as complete required reading on the history of the Park. Orientation sessions include lectures, workshops, and on-site tours. Orientation takes place on Saturday, April 6 and 13 (attendance required at one orientation session only). By the end of orientation, each docent will be prepared to answer all matter of questions from park visitors.
summary: WSPC is accepting new volunteers into its Greeter-Tour Program, a program that interacts with Park users, helping them learn about the exciting horticulture, history, events, and culture that the Park has to offer. From our resident hawks to the coveted Arch, the Park has many stories to be told!
title: Washington Square Park Conservancy
